content.title: Prosthetic Vascular Graft Infection
content.definition: Prosthetic vascular graft infection is bacterial colonization and infection of a synthetic vascular graft, a devastating complication with high morbidity and mortality, typically requiring graft excision and extra-anatomic reconstruction.

clinical_presentation.occult_presentation: May present only with anastomotic pseudoaneurysm or GI bleed
clinical_presentation.aortoenteric_fistula: Herald bleed followed by massive GI hemorrhage

imaging.ct_with_contrast: Perigraft fluid, air (after 6 weeks), pseudoaneurysm, bowel adherence
imaging.fdg_pet_ct: Increased uptake at graft - useful for occult infection

diagnosis.cultures: Blood cultures, wound cultures, intraoperative cultures (tissue, not swab)

total_excision_extra_anatomic.approach: Remove infected graft, axillofemoral bypass through clean field
total_excision_extra_anatomic.disadvantage: Aortic stump blowout risk, inferior patency

surgical_options.conservative: Partial excision, debridement, muscle flap coverage (selected cases)

treatment.antibiotics: Prolonged IV (4-6 weeks), then oral suppression if prosthetic remains

definition.@value: Bacterial colonization and infection of a synthetic vascular graft requiring graft excision and reconstruction

medicalCode.description: Infection and inflammatory reaction due to other cardiac and vascular devices, implants and grafts

learning_objectives: Apply Szilagyi and Samson classification systems
Describe microbiology of early vs late graft infections
Compare surgical treatment options for graft infection
Identify imaging findings of graft infection
clinical_pearls: S. aureus is most common in early infections, coagulase-negative staph in late
Groin incisions have highest infection rate
CT showing perigraft air after 6 weeks is abnormal and suggests infection
Herald GI bleed should prompt evaluation for aortoenteric fistula
pedagogical.board_yield: HIGH - major complication with high mortality
